subtitle: Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I imagine
that by now many of you already realize that
in conjunction with White Crow Books we've just
launched the new Thinking Allowed Dialogues
book imprint, and our first title is, Is There Life After Death?
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey
Mishlove. Today is a very special video. Many of
the viewers will know Leanne Whitney, who has
been a guest on New Thinking Allowed many times.
She is the author of the book Consciousness
in Jung and Patanjali and is an expert on yoga
and psychology. However, before Leanne received
her doctoral degree, before she wrote her book,
she was a filmmaker. In 2005, she came to Las
Vegas where I was then living and conducted an
in-depth interview with me, which has never been
released before until now. I'm going to turn it
over to Leanne who will introduce this video.
Thank you, Jeff. Nice to be with you and the
New Thinking Allowed audience again. I do. I
want to set up the context for this because it's,
oh my gosh, almost two decades old at this point.
After I had had my Pure Consciousness event,
which we spoke about briefly in one of the episodes we did on New Thinking Allowed,
and I was in a yoga room and it was very instantaneous, but it was
an awakening to the fact that consciousness is all
there is and really that knowledge is structured
in it. As a creative, as an artist, I wanted
to make a film about the evolution of human
consciousness. Again, this is the early aughts. I
remember when I reached out to you to potentially
be in the film, you had said to me, boy, you are
taking on a really big topic. Really that ended
up being the case, but I came to your home in
Las Vegas and we sat down and we talked for an
hour or so and pulling that footage out now,
it really, it holds the test of time because my
original idea, again, almost 20 years ago, in this
movie of the evolution of human consciousness,
and again, I think you and I agree, it's really
just the evolution of consciousness and it's a
realization for human beings, but I thought
intuition and sigh is really a great way for people
to learn about clearing the lens of perception
and leaving behind that illusion of separation
and I think rewinding and now cutting together
this piece, again, that message really stands out
and so I'm happy to be sharing it with your viewership and to be with you here again on
New Thinking Allowed.
Jeffrey. Hello, Leanne. Hi. Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you, too. Come right in. Thank you.
How are you? I'm doing well. Did you have a good trip? Yes, it was great.
Thanks very much. Welcome. Thank you very much.
So your friend, Peter, had recommended that I come
see you because Peter and I were talking about the
evolution of mankind and is mankind potentially
at a place right now? We're almost at the fork
in the road. Either we're going to make a choice
to heal ourselves as a species or potentially
annihilate ourselves. Do you have an opinion on
that or do you believe that's where we are? Well,
it might be that Las Vegas is a city that sort of
embodies that choice here. It represents, in
a way, the most materialistic place on Earth.
It's also the most popular destination on the
planet. So I see it as something of a turning
point. Yeah. Humanity is at a crisis. We have
the power to destroy ourselves. We literally,
for the first time in human history, we do have
that power and there are lots of signs already.
I'm sure you and Peter talked about pollution
being a big one and nuclear weapons being another
big one and oppression and so on. Yeah, so I do
agree. Right. But can I add one more little thing?
Oh, of course. I wouldn't say mankind. Okay.
I would say humanity or something. Like you're
leaving the other half out, womankind. I gotcha.
That's a problem right there. Right, right, right.
Sure. Yeah, the human species in general. Absolutely. Okay, so that's a potential.
But also, do you feel like we're evolving as a species? Is that a potential as well?
It's almost as if we have deliberately brought
ourselves to a point of crisis in order to
force ourselves to evolve or go extinct.
And if you look at the history of evolution,
you can see that this has happened many times
in the past. A classic example, some of our very
first biological ancestors were anaerobic
bacteria and they didn't breathe oxygen. In fact,
oxygen was a poisonous waste gas that they produced and it got to the point where our
earliest ancestors were drowning in their own
pollution, this terrible gas oxygen, and they
evolved to become oxygen breathers. And throughout
the history of evolution on this planet, there have
been these, it's called the theory of punctuated
equilibrium. Crises keep coming up and as a
response every time, if you look at evolution,
life itself has evolved, but many species end
up going extinct nonetheless. Right, right,
fascinating. So what is this exact point then
that you see? So like you mentioned that point of
oxygen usage or toxicity, so what is it right now?
Like what is the toxic point? Well, if you look at the problems facing this planet,
they're almost all caused by people. We've had
a tsunami recently, that's a terrible natural
disaster, but the problems of the ecology are
generally created by human beings. The problems
of warfare are human problems, the problems of oppression and suppression of different
political and racial and religious groups.
Those are human problems, the problem of the
inequality of the sexes and discrimination of
all sorts. These are human problems and because
we have this awesome nuclear power, this ability
to literally, I don't think we would destroy the
planet, I don't think we would destroy all life,
but we have the power to pretty much destroy the
human species if it were unleashed. Right, right,
right. So I guess what I'm trying to get at is
let's distill the problem down to its nutshell
and what I hear you talking about is a lot of
violence, first of all, violence towards each
other, violence towards the mother in general.
So why the violence? I mean, because my whole
thing is, at the end of the day, I really feel
that all men, all women, all human beings in
general want two things, one in particular,
which is love. That's what we all want, is to
love, and the other thing is peace. So, and again,
that's my gut response to being a human and
what we want. So why the violence then? Well,
nature maybe doesn't agree with you on this.
It's sort of human to want those things,
and I want them too. I think it's the most
wonderful thing in the world to be a loving and
peaceful person, but if you look at nature
as a whole, it's violent, it's punctuated by
all sorts of savagery, and you might say that
all of nature feeds upon itself, ultimately.
Right, right. So, and the system may not have been designed that way,
and in a way it's still all perfect. I'm perfectly
happy to accept that this wouldn't exist at all.
There would be nothing here if it wasn't in the finest tuned balance.
Okay. Well, what do you see as the potential
choice for the human species not to annihilate
itself, to stay, or to not go extinct, but to
flourish and continue to evolve? What does that
path look like? What are our choices there? Well,
it seems to me that a lot of our problems are
created because we live under certain illusions.
You know, in yoga they call it Maya, the idea that
they're illusions. In Buddhism, they call it
Dukkha. It's a kind of insanity that permeates
everything, and one of the most fundamental
illusions that we live under is the idea that
there is a basic separation between me and
everything that is not me. That, for example,
I'm a person, and you're a person, and we are
separate and distinct. Or that I'm separate from
this chair or from these books. That there is such
a thing as a me that exists at all, separate and
distinct. And therefore, I want to fight to
preserve that sense that I have of me, so that
I can live forever and accumulate as much as I
might desire. Actually, I think that is an illusion.
Me is simply a concept that I have in my
mind. The truth of the matter is that I am a
a nexus in the quantum foam, and I'm
intimately interconnected with all of creation.
So we have social groups, you know, where it sort
of evolves. Now I'm not only going to protect
my own sense of identity, I'll protect my family,
I'll protect my tribe, I'll protect my nation.
And so now we have a so-called war on terrorism,
and that means that in order to protect what we
identify with as ourselves, it doesn't matter if
we go and kill other people, because they're not
us. They're the enemy. They're somehow separate,
distinct, other. And this very concept of
otherness, I think, is a problem. You could
say it's about duality. As soon as you accept
the idea of duality, you get into good and evil.
Good and evil means usually to ask just about
anybody, whether it's an Arab fundamentalist or
the President of the United States, they'd say
good and evil means I'm good and you're evil.
So if I want to kill you, I'm fighting evil,
and that's a good thing. And it's a fundamental
error in my view, because it's a denial of the
wholeness, it's a denial of the oneness, and that's
the realm of spirit. Right, okay. So basically
that there's annihilation and the other four
obviously is to continue to evolve, and you see
that as the dissolution of separateness, the
dissolution of ego or I-identity, and the embracing
of the wholeness, of the unity, of the oneness.
I do see it that way, but I don't think, Leanne,
that it means that we want to sacrifice our egos
on the altar of some kind of spirituality. There
are lots of cults and groups where they say you
have to let go of yourself and just be a spiritual
person and give up that ego. That's not the way
to do it, because we were put on this planet for a
reason. We were brought into physical manifestation
for a reason, and in my view that reason,
it's not just to merge back to the oneness from
which we came without doing anything first,
it's to achieve a sense of mastery of this planet
and of the physical world that surrounds us. Not
necessarily mastery over other people, but mastery
over ourselves and mastery over physical reality,
and it's through the path of mastery, I think,
that we can achieve this understanding that I've
described of unity, the fundamental unity of things. I think what you're saying, too,
is the uniqueness in the unity. Yes, we're all one, but we all have the capability of,
I think Young calls it individuation or whatever,
but being that individual and being that unique
expression of the one. Exactly, you put it
beautifully. Yeah, okay. Well, how do you think
we connect to the spirit then? Because what I
see, I guess, is maybe a disconnection and maybe,
again, that's what causes a lot of the anger and frustration and the separateness,
that separate identity, because we're not infused
with the spiritual identity. So how do we get there?
We are infused with it, and we've lost
touch. Okay. We look for answers externally,
outside of ourselves. We find answers in our
religions and our sciences and our institutions
of commerce and business, and they'll all be
happy to create a culture that emphasizes duality
and separateness so that people are constrained
to obey their leaders and they're afraid of the
other out there. But when we look within instead
of without, that's where we'll find spirit,
and that's why I'm involved in the Intuition
Network. It's all about basically encouraging
people to look within, to find answers within
themselves rather than to trust authority of any
kind. What is intuition exactly then? How do
you define intuition? Well, it's a Latin word
originally, intuary, which means to look within.
Intuition is, it usually is knowledge that comes
to us from a place that's so deep that it's beneath
consciousness. Sometimes you know something you
shouldn't know without knowing how you know it.
That's how profound intuition can be, and it
manifests in many different ways in science and
language and art and commerce. But ultimately,
I think intuition is an expression of spirit and
inner spirit, and specifically what I mean by
spirit, it's an expression of our life purpose.
I think each individual is born with a purpose.
That's a concept that is almost totally alien to
science. Science can deal with cause and effect,
but not purpose so much, and yet you're here with
me right now because you're motivated by something
inside of you, a purpose, a sense of direction,
a sense of longing, of questing, and of moving
towards something, and each person is that.
And when people say to themselves, I want to
get in touch with my purpose, I want to live a
life that is based on purpose, then at the level
of spirit things begin to happen to support that
intention. Right, okay. Well, are there specific
tools or ways that people can get in touch with
their intuition? Because obviously you believe
that everybody has it. So let's just say, okay,
let's go back to Jung for a second because I'm
an extroverted thinker. So you know intuition
maybe isn't necessarily my first function,
you know what I'm saying, if you go to his
typology kind of thing. So if you're not used to,
you know, if you're more of a thinker or a feeler, how do you know intuition?
We're using the word a little differently
here. Carl Jung, the great Swiss psychiatrist,
talked about four human mental functions, thinking, feeling, sensing, and intuiting.
So it's one of four, and I'm referring to
something having to do with the level of spirit,
which underlies all of those, but is
particularly identified with what Jung called
intuition. Okay. And I think, you see, we all use
it all the time. Anyway, we don't even know it.
Everybody is an expert in intuition. That's the
funniest thing, and people don't know that they
are typically. So if I were to be like traditional
about it, I'd say, oh, you should meditate,
you should practice yoga breathing, that'll help you get in touch with your intuition,
learn to quiet your mind. But the truth is that,
let's think of a totally chaotic scene for a
moment, a mother with a screaming baby, and she's
trying to cook dinner, and the TV is blaring.
That mother probably knows an extraordinary amount
about intuition. She's in touch with every nuance
of what the baby is thinking, and feeling, and
needing. And if the baby gets a pin, pops out of
the diaper, and pokes into the baby, the mother
will be there right away. So mothers and their
children just naturally experience intuition.
Martial artists who are very active, not at all
passive, experience intuition naturally through their discipline. So do athletes.
People who pay attention to their dreams get in
touch with their intuition. People in business,
if you talk to almost anybody who have founded a
successful business, it was based on an intuition,
and it can come to people in the most unexpected
ways. Martin Luther, who founded the whole
Christian Reformation, I understand, the intuition
came to him while he was sitting on the toilet.
So there's no limitation to how intuition
works, and everybody does it most of the time.
I'll give you an example, really graphic. You
know what I'm saying. The words, the sounds,
that are coming out of my mouth make sense to you
because intuitively you're grasping my meaning.
And I know what noise to make next out of
intuition. All language is intuitively based,
actually. So we all live with it all of the time,
and yet society denigrates it. Society will tell
us that thinking is good, feeling is good,
sensing is good, but intuition isn't supported
by society. In fact, a young child growing up in a family, if they get too intuitive,
will frighten their parents. The parents may discourage it, and in school it may be
discouraged as well. So it's the one function we tend to suppress.
I think there's deep metaphysical reasons for
that, actually. You can think of it this way,
Leanne. What game do children all over the world play universally?
Can I throw out an answer? Hide and seek?
Exactly. That is it. Every culture, children
know how to play hide and seek. And to me,
it's a metaphor for why we're here in the first place. We're all the children of,
you could say the children of God, of course,
but we're all evolved. Originally, our source
is a spiritual source. We're descended from the
one spirit. You could say, well, we came up from
the slime, according to Darwinian evolution,
and that's also true. But at the same time that
we arose from the slime, we descended from the realm of spirit in our consciousness.
And we've come here on a spiritual quest, ultimately, but part of that quest involves
hiding, hiding from ourselves, and then rediscovering ourselves. And part of how we
hide is through our society, through a social
reality that gets created where we all kind of
pretend to agree that it's not true, that we have
this divine spark within each and every one of us.
So do you think the intuition then potentially,
you know, is maybe a large part of that answer?
Because if our intuition is our connection to
spirit, and what we're doing here is discovering that our source is spirit,
intuition might be a large part of the answer
going back to that fork and potentially evolving
and where we're going. Yeah, that's why we're
having this conversation, I suppose. And
the way to help get over the social pressure, not
to be in touch with your intuition, is to find
a few really good friends who you can be with
in a regular way and support each other and
encourage each other and honor and respect the
intuitive part of each other, instead of kind of
giving it negative feedback that so many social
institutions will do, give it positive feedback
instead, and recognize that everyone is already
an expert, and then help bring that out.
Right, right, right. Small groups of people.
Right, as well, start small, right? Starts
with one and then you kind of move out and
into your little group and then the community.
That's what the intuition network is, in a sense,
it's a network of small groups of people who
help encourage each other to just be in touch with that part of reality.
And so does that look like a healing reality to you? Like? Absolutely.
Healing for self, healing for community, healing
for the mother, I mean, just healing all over the
place? All over the place. And again, it's a
paradox because everything's already perfect.
Right. What's there to heal? But at the same time,
my sense is that as people get in touch with their
own inner spirit, well, what emerges or what it's
called in religious terms, the gifts of the spirit
or the siddhis or the psychic gifts, and amongst
those is the gift of healing. And as people become
more and more conscious, they realize, and it's
now been well documented in scientific research,
that our intentions, our thoughts and our
intentions, make a difference. And if you have
healing intention towards a particular person,
towards a plant, an animal, towards the planet
as a whole, towards God as a whole, those
intentions manifest. And certainly in experiments
involving people can be measured in double-blind
tests. Interesting, interesting, because I always
have the question, you know, because today there's so much talk about consciousness,
but my understanding of the brain is there's
a large portion of it actually held in the
unconscious. And I know in my own life, my unconscious thoughts have precedence over
my conscious. No matter how much I want to
like talk my way into one thing, if there's an
unconscious behavioral pattern going on, it's
going to show up. But if the underlying intention,
like you said, is healing or something, let's
just say altruistic, I don't know if that's the
right word, then you will get there. You know
what I'm saying? Like the unconscious aspects will
come up into the consciousness and it will be
healed and a wholeness will take place. Does
that make sense? Well, I think part of the
process I referred to earlier of acquiring mastery
involves making the unconscious conscious. It's
one of the reasons we're here. And you see it all
over these days, especially in the media, all
these TV shows where people are now talking about
subjects that were taboo only a few decades ago.
It's a way of revealing at a socially collective
level all of our inner drives and conflicts and
urges and lusts and so on. So that comes out and
then we can process it. Then we can, through
feedback, we can look at ourselves. And as
we move through the realms, like in particular
our addictions, our desires, the things we
lust after, you get in touch with what I would
call not just the unconscious, but the super
conscious mind. A super conscious mind is your
higher desires, your longing for union, your
longing for a sense of oneness, for a spiritual
connection. And ultimately it seems to me, Leanne,
that many of the things that we act out in life, particularly let's say drug addiction
or many things that people do in relationships,
what they're really looking for is a spiritual
connection. But because there's not a lot of
support for that in our culture, that drive gets
misplaced. And some people, they seek food or
they seek drugs or they seek sex when what they
really want is to connect with their own spirit.
Right, so they externalize. They externalize it
instead of internalizing again intuition and
bringing it in and inside and connecting that way.
So really then in order to think, in order to
have the greatest amount of healing or mastery
or spiritual connection, it's about peeling
back those layers, cleaning those layers of the
unconscious and bringing all that stuff forward
and understanding yourself. I mean that's what
self-mastery is really. Know thyself, right?
Right. It's a process that takes place on many
levels. You could say physical disciplines
like yoga, athletics, the martial arts. It's a
psychological process that we've been talking
about. It's also philosophical. It involves
having an intellectual framework that can fit
all of these things in. An intellectual framework
where there's room for the very idea of spirit.
Right, is there room for that right now?
In our world, how much room do we have for that?
Well, there are competing forces in our culture
right now. There are the traditionalists who
basically maintain, you know, the conversation
that you and I are now having is dangerous, new
age sort of thing and that it's not in accordance
with scripture or not in accordance with theology
and it's not good for people to be intuitive
because they could be misled by their own base
desires and confuse those for intuition so they
ought to pay attention to scripture and to
what their churches are telling them instead
rather than to be intuitive. On the other hand,
then you have the scientific modernists who would
say, well, intuition is just an illusion. We've
got to be rational. We've got to base our thinking
on materialism. We have to understand that any
sense of mystery is an illusion, that this world
is all very cause and effect based. There's no
sense of purpose. There's no sense of a spiritual
quest at all. It's just, from this point of view, an effort to return back to the womb
into a kind of infantile state. So between those two forces,
there needs to be a balance. There needs to be
an openness to the spiritual side of religion,
the authentic spirituality that permeates religion.
At the same time, there needs to be an openness
to the rigors of science and to the empirical
data of science. But if you look at science
as rigorously as you can, science is based on a philosophy called empiricism.
Empiricism says that what is real is what we experience through our senses.
Right, right, right.
I'm a student of William James, the great psychologist who looked a little deeper,
and he said, well, where do we get our sensory
information from? We get it from consciousness.
Even underlying our senses is consciousness,
and if we can look directly into consciousness,
which is what intuition is, that's what he
called radical empiricism. That's taking the
empiricist philosophy all the way, and the
information that comes directly from consciousness
is even more direct than the information that
appears through our senses. It, therefore,
deserves to be recognized and admitted into scientific discourse.
It's not just the five senses that we really
know. It's moving beyond the five senses into
the subtle senses that aren't necessarily honored today.
They're not honored, but now we have for over
a hundred years a big body of research in the
fields of parapsychology and near-death experience
and psychic healing and human potential. Dream
research is another area that points to the validity of these areas.
Right. Do you think maybe intuitive healers or even psychics are maybe on the forefront
of this evolution? Yeah, I personally do, although
I know what a difficult time it is. I have
hundreds of dear friends who are psychics through
the Intuition Network, and they live in a world
where they don't get a lot of social support.
They're under extra stress, and it's not easy.
To be a psychic under those circumstances is any
more than it would be to be a member of any other
persecuted minority. And so, as a consequence,
the world of intuition and psychics is a little
bit like a ghetto. It has its own culture. It has
its richness and its vibrancy, and also its pain.
And if I can elaborate a little. Yeah, absolutely, because I have a lot of
friends who are psychics too, you know. So go
ahead, yeah. Well, pain is an important topic
to deal with here. I saw your movie, The Fire
Within, and I know what you were dealing with
there was pain, people who were experiencing
enormous inner pain and yet also a great vibrancy
and joy of life. And I commend you for making
that film because we live in a culture where
we don't want to see other people's pain. And the reason is because it's painful.
And so one of the things that we do is we
become numb. It's easier to feel nothing at all
sometimes than to have to take in the pain of the
world. But as we open up to this idea of oneness,
if I open up to the idea that I am you, you are me, then how can I not feel your pain?
And I have to let it in. That's part of the art
of becoming intuitive is being willing to take in
the pain of the world, at least a little bit more
than we normally do. And one of the reasons why
there's this subtle conspiracy to dampen our
intuition is because then we don't have to.
Experience so much pain. And how else can we
oppress other people? How else can we engage
in warfare? Or can we tolerate situations where
millions of people starve to death in a world
where there's plenty of food? Unless we dampen that sense of their pain.
Absolutely. And Peter and I touched upon this
when we spoke as well. And that's what really
saddens me as a human being right now on this
planet at this time. How can we be so desensitized?
It comes down, I think, to willingness and
courage to want to open the heart and want to sit
and feel all of that, feel what it means to be
human, which there's a lot of feelings involved
in that. It's wanting to express the emotional body,
so to speak. I don't know if it's predominantly
here in the West or if this is a global thing
or whatever, but really allowing our emotional
bodies to express themselves. Well, people get
overwhelmed by their emotions and we don't get
a lot of social support for doing that. And there's so much pain in the world it's hard
to take it in sometimes without getting
overwhelmed. Just one little thing, starvation
is a huge thing. Millions of people die every
year from starvation. Thousands every day
from starvation, unnecessarily. It's a situation
that can only exist because people have sort of
pushed it out of their awareness. We don't want
to know. And it goes even deeper, I think. I don't
want to go on a crusade about vegetarianism, but
I'm a vegetarian and I made that decision actually
recently when it occurred to me that killing
animals for food causes a lot of unnecessary pain.
I don't think everybody needs to make that decision and I'm not going on about it,
but I do know that in many spiritual traditions
there is a moment where time is taken to
acknowledge that sacrifice that an animal makes so people at least are aware of
what is involved in just putting food on their plates.
Yeah, and I think that just that goes back to
spirit being infused in our lives in general.
If you look at the Native Americans or a lot
of primitive cultures, they had a lot of that
reverence, again, for the mother, for spirit.
You know, and we're seemingly, I mean, I know
that I was cut off from that for a long time.
I had to go seek it to find out what it was and,
you know, picking up Gary Zhukov's Seed of the
Soul is really what did it for me. It really
opened my mind because I grew up a Catholic.
That didn't speak to me at all. I didn't understand that whole fear-based
God-outside-themselves kind of idea, but when
I picked up the idea that we are spirit and
we are one with it all, it really, really rang true to me. So I guess my question is,
where did we go? Where in the evolutionary track
did we go so far off? Because I think we had it
before. Like, maybe we're coming back to it.
Well, there are different theories about it.
There's a beautiful story that's told in the
Jewish mystical tradition about how that happened.
The story is Moses goes up to the top of Mount
Sinai to receive the Ten Commandments, the Torah,
and he was given by God what they call the Torah
of the Book of Life. And the Book of Life is this
way of seeing the world of oneness, the unity with
all of life and all of nature. And Moses is now
coming down the mountain with the Torah of the
Book of Life to give to the people. And what does
he see? He sees them worshipping the golden
calf. And he gets incensed. He gets so angry
at what they're doing after he brought them out
of slavery in Egypt that he takes the tablets
and he smashes them on the ground. And at this
point, according to the oral tradition, the letters
from the tablets flew back up to heaven. And
then Moses went back up again a second time
to the top of Mount Sinai. And this time, he
said, the people aren't ready for the Torah
of the Book of Life. So he was given a different
Torah, which is the Torah of the Book of Knowledge
of Good and Evil, the Torah of duality, right
and wrong, do thou shalt and thou shalt not.
And that's the one that he brought down because
the people weren't ready. So now the mystical
traditions are the traditions involved in bringing
back the Torah of the Book of Life instead of the
Torah of the Book of Knowledge of Good and Evil.
Interestingly, which brings me to another point,
which I don't understand is, you know, isn't
